title: 110_hr1105
content: The "Physician Pathology Services Continuity Act of 2007" is the short title of the Act. It addresses the permanent treatment of certain physician pathology services under Medicare. The "Physician Pathology Services Continuity Act of 2007" amends Section 1848(i) of the Social Security Act to specify the treatment of physician pathology services under Medicare, particularly regarding payment to independent laboratories for technical components provided to fee-for-service Medicare beneficiaries in hospitals. The "Physician Pathology Services Continuity Act of 2007" amends Section 1848(i) of the Social Security Act to specify payment to hospitals for outpatient services provided by independent laboratories to Medicare beneficiaries. The "Physician Pathology Services Continuity Act of 2007" amends Section 1848(i) of the Social Security Act to specify payment to hospitals for outpatient services provided by independent laboratories to Medicare beneficiaries. Inpatients or outpatients can submit claims for payment to a carrier under section 1842, not to the hospital, regardless of ownership changes. The term 'fee-for-service Medicare beneficiary' is also defined. The term 'fee-for-service Medicare beneficiary' refers to an individual entitled to Medicare benefits under part A or enrolled in part B, but not enrolled in Medicare Advantage, an eligible organization plan, PACE, or SHMO demonstration. The SHMO demonstration project was established under the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1987. For the treatment of certain physician pathology services furnished before January 1, 2008, refer to section 542 of the Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Benefits Improvement and Protection Act of 2000. The SHMO demonstration project was established under the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1987. Relevant references include CMS Manual System, Publication 100-20 One-Time Notification (transmittal 34), section 732 of the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003, and section 104 of division B of the Tax Relief and Health Care Act of 2006.
